ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained insights into formulating problems into models of game theory and solving them.
I better understand mathematically rigorous game theory and what is required for a proof.
Game theory, different equilibrium concepts etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The first part of this course (game theory) should be better structured in terms of organization. The topics should be more clearly defined and distinguished from each other.
Very well organized and concise lecture notes
More examples. More test preparation materials.

The homework was often comically difficult compared to the material covered in lecture. It often felt like two different courses (particularly for the first half of the course). It did feel like we covered the range of game theory topics fairly extensively.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It is a required first year PhD course.
If someone wants to actually produce game theory models, this course is a necessity.
